contextId.information: "as they watched." The apostles "were looking up" at Jesus because Jesus rose into the sky. AT: "as they were looking up at the sky" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the distance which, according to Rabbinical tradition, a person was allowed to walk on a Sabbath day. AT: "about one kilometer away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

"the money that he earned from the evil thing that he did." The words "his wickedness" refer to Judas Iscariot's betraying Jesus to the people who killed him. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: the earnings he received for his wickedness

contextId.information: This suggests that Judas fell from a high place, rather than just falling down. The fall was severe enough to cause his body to burst open. Other passages of scripture mention that he hanged himself. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: there he fell headfirst, and his body burst open, and all his intestines poured out

contextId.information: Here the word "They" refers to all of the believers who were present. AT: "They proposed two men who fulfilled the requirements that Peter listed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here the word "They" refers to all of the believers, but it was probably one of the apostles who spoke these words. AT: "The believers prayed together and one of the apostles said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"It is only nine o'clock in the morning" (UDB). Peter expected his audience to know that people do not get drunk that early in the day. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: it is only the third hour of the day

contextId.information: "They were very angry." The Sadducees, in particular, would have been angry about what Peter and John were saying because they did not believe in resurrection. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here the word "boldness" refers to the way in which Peter and John responded to the Jewish leaders. AT: "how boldly Peter and John had spoken" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
contextId.quote: the boldness of Peter and John

contextId.information: The Jewish leaders "realized" this because of the way Peter and John spoke. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: realized that they were ordinary, uneducated men

contextId.information: Here the word "it" refers to any miracles or teaching Peter and John might continue to do. AT: "in order that no more people hear about this miracle" "in order that news of this miracle spreads no further" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: in order that it spreads no further

contextId.information: The phrase "their own people" refers to the rest of the believers. AT: "went to the other believers" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
They did not go into the temple building where only the priests were allowed. AT: "in the temple courtyard ... into the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: in the temple ... into the temple

contextId.information: The words "no one" refer to the apostles. This implies that there was no one else in the jail cell besides the apostles. AT: "we did not find them inside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
They did not go into the part of the temple building where only the priests were allowed. AT: "standing in the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Gamaliel is telling the Jewish leaders no to punish the apostles any more or to put them back in jail. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: keep away from these men and let them alone

contextId.information: These are Greek names, and suggest that all of the men elected were from the Grecian Jewish group of believers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The words "grace" and "power" here refer to power from God. This could be stated explicitly. AT: "God was giving Stephen power to do" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Stephen, full of grace and power, was doing

contextId.information: The Jews would have understood that this covenant required Abraham to circumcise the males of his family. AT: "made a covenant with Abraham to circumcise the males of his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: gave Abraham the covenant of circumcision

contextId.information: The Jews knew their ancestors sold Joseph to be a slave in Egypt. AT: "sold him as a slave in Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Both of these phrases refer to Joseph's older brothers. The UDB makes this explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to his people, and not just to his family. AT: "see how his own people, the children of Israel, were doing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: visit his brothers, the children of Israel

contextId.information: The audience would have known from the account in Exodus that these were two men, but Stephen does not specify that. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The implied information is that Moses understood that the Israelites knew that he had killed an Egyptian the day before ([[:en:bible:notes:act:07:26|7:28]]). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Stephen's audience knew that God spoke through the angel. The UDB makes this explicit.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Moses was surprised that the bush was not burning up in the fire. This was previously known by Stephen's audience. AT: "because the bush was not burning up" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Moses shook from fear. This can be made clear. AT: "Moses trembled with fear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The implied information is that where God is present, the immediate area around God is considered or made holy by God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: for the place where you are standing is holy ground

contextId.information: Stephen's audience knew about the forty years the Israelites spent in the wilderness. AT: "during the 40 years that the Israelite people lived in the wilderness" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Stephen's audience knew the calf they made was a statue. AT: "they made a statue that looked like a calf" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that they took these idols with them as they traveled in the wilderness. AT: "you carried with you from place to place" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
People normally experienced the glory of God as a bright light. AT: "saw a bright light from God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to men and women who believed in Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This implies that he was a Gentile who believed in God and had come to worship at the Jewish temple. AT: "He had come to worship God at the temple in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He had come to Jerusalem to worship

contextId.information: "he might take them as prisoners to Jerusalem." Paul's purpose can be made clear by adding "so that the Jewish leaders could judge and punish them" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: he might bring them bound to Jerusalem

contextId.information: This implies that he had closed his eyes because the light was too bright. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is implied that the extent of the power and authority granted Saul was limited to the Jewish people at this point in time. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Caesarea was a seaport. They brothers probably sent Saul to Tarsus by ship. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to the time when Peter was in Joppa. This can be stated. AT: "It came about while Peter was nearby" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: It came about in those days

contextId.information: It is implied that his gifts and prayers had been accepted by God. AT: "God is pleased by your prayers and your gifts ... a memorial offering to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Your prayers and your gifts ... a memorial offering into God's presence

contextId.information: From Peter's response in the next verse, it can be implied that the law of Moses commanded the Jews not to eat some of them. AT: "animals and birds that the Mosaic laws forbade Jews to eat" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: all kinds of four-footed animals ... birds of the sky

contextId.information: It is implied that some the animals in the container were unclean as defined by the law of Moses and were not to be eaten by believers who lived before Christ died. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I have never eaten anything that was defiled and unclean

contextId.information: "stood before the gate to the house." It is implied that this house had a wall with a gate in it to enter the property. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"many Gentile people gathered together." It is implied that these people Cornelius had invited were Gentiles. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

From Peter's response, it can be implied that the law of Moses commanded the Jews not to eat some of them. AT: "animals and birds that the Mosaic laws forbade Jews to eat." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:act:10:09|10:12]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These Greek-speaking people were Gentiles, not Jews. AT: "also spoke to Gentiles who spoke Greek" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

That Herod planned to execute him can be clarified. AT: "The happened on the day before Herod was going to bring Peter out from prison to put him on trial and then to execute him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: On the night before Herod was going to bring him out for trial

contextId.information: It is implied that the soldiers were not able to see Peter and the angel as they walked by. AT: "The first and second guards did not see them as they passed by, and then" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: After they had passed by the first guard and the second

contextId.information: This refers back to when they brought money from the believers at Antioch in [[:en:bible:notes:act:11:29|11:29-30]]. AT: "delivered the money to the church leaders in Jerusalem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
John was referring to the Messiah, whom they were expecting to come. AT: "I am not the Messiah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This also refers to the Messiah. AT: "The Messiah will soon come" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It may be helpful to explicitly say Jesus died before this happened. AT: "they killed Jesus and then took him down from the cross after he died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: they took him down from the tree

contextId.information: Paul's audience would have understood that this Psalm refers to the Messiah. AT: "In another Psalm of David, he also says about the Messiah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: This is why he also says in another Psalm

contextId.information: It is implied that they believed Paul's message that Jesus was the Messiah. AT: "to continue to trust that God kindly forgives people's sins because of what Jesus did" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: to continue in the grace of God

contextId.information: This implies that God had commanded this be done. AT: "God commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"spoke so powerfully." It may be helpful to state that they spoke the message about Jesus. AT: "spoke the message about Jesus so powerfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
A large number of people believed Paul and Barnabas were their pagan gods who had come down from heaven. AT: "The gods have come down from heaven to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The gods have come down to us

contextId.information: It may be helpful to include additional information about the priest. AT: "There was a temple just outside the city where the people worshiped Zeus. When the priest who served in the temple heard what Paul and Barnabas had done, he brought" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The priest of Zeus, whose temple was just outside the city, brought

contextId.information: It my be helpful to explicitly state what they persuaded the crowd to do. AT: "persuaded the people not to believe Paul and Barnabas, and to turn against them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Some men." You can make explicit that these men were Jews who believed in Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here "brothers" stands for believers in Christ. It is implied that they were in Antioch. AT: "taught the believers at Antioch" or "were teaching the believers at Antioch" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

You can make explicit in what way James does not want to trouble the Gentiles. AT: "we should not require the Gentiles to become circumcised and obey the laws of Moses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: we should not trouble those of the Gentiles

contextId.information: This possibly refers to eating the meat of an animal that someone has sacrificed to an idol or to anything to do with idol worship. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

God did not allow Jews to eat meat that still had the blood in it. Also, even earlier in Moses' writings in Genesis, God had forbidden the drinking of blood. Therefore, they could not eat an animal that someone strangled because the blood was not properly drained from the body of the animal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: from the meat of strangled animals, and from blood

contextId.information: Here "church" refers to the people who are a part of the church in Jerusalem. AT: "the church in Jerusalem" or "the whole community of believers in Jerusalem" (See: (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This phrase emphasizes that Judas and Silas will say the same things that the apostles and elders had written. AT: "who themselves will tell you the same things about which we have written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: who will tell you the same thing themselves in their own words

contextId.information: This refers to drinking blood or eating meat from which the blood has not been drained. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Since Greek men did not have their sons circumcised, the Jews would have known Timothy was not circumcised, and they would have rejected Paul and Timothy before hearing their message about Christ. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: for they all knew that his father was a Greek

contextId.information: This is a city outside of Italy where many people who came from Rome lived. It had the same rights and freedoms as a city in Italy. They could govern themselves and they did not have to pay taxes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The reason why the jailer needed light can be made explicit. AT: "called for someone to bring light so he could see who was still in the prison" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Probably Paul is speaking to the jailer, but he intends for the jailer to tell the magistrates what he says. AT: "said to the jailer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Paul explained what the scriptures means in order to prove to the Jews that Jesus is the Messiah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: reasoned with them from the scriptures

contextId.information: It can be stated explicitly what the Lord wants Paul to speak. AT: "and do not stop speaking about the gospel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It is made explicit in the next few verses that Paul remains in Ephesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: But he himself stayed in Asia for a while

contextId.information: You can make explicit that Alexander was trying to quieten the crowd. AT: "gestured to the audience to be quiet so that he could make an explanation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
They had to make themselves ritually pure so they could worship in the temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Take these men and purify yourself with them

contextId.information: "pay for what they will need." The expenses would go toward buying a male and female lamb, a ram, and grain and drink offerings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

All of these are rules about what they can eat. They are forbidden to eat meat of animals sacrificed to an idol, meat with blood still in it, and meat from a strangled animal because it would still have blood in the meat. See how you translated similar phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:act:15:19|15:20]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: they should keep themselves from things sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what is strangled

contextId.information: This can be stated in active form. You can also state explicitly the assumed information about strangled animals. AT: "from animals that a person has strangled" or "from animals that a person killed for food but did not drain its blood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Only Jewish males were allowed in certain areas of the courtyard of the Jerusalem temple. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Besides, he has also brought Greeks into the temple

contextId.information: It can be stated explicitly why Paul motioned with the hand. AT: "motioned with his hand for the people to be quiet" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: motioned with the hand to the people

contextId.information: The phrase "Nazarene sect" is another name for the Christians. AT: "He also leads the entire group whom people call the followers of the Nazarene" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He is a leader of the Nazarene sect

contextId.information: This can be stated as a separate new sentence. AT: "I had not gathered a crowd nor was I trying to start a riot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: not with a crowd or an uproar

contextId.information: You can make explicit what kinds of questions this means. AT: "and questions about religious matters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit that Christ must also die. AT: "that Christ must suffer and die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit that they got off of the ship in Myra. AT: "came to Myra, a city of Lycia, where we got off the ship" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: came to Myra, a city of Lycia

contextId.information: It is implied that a crew would sail the ship to Italy. AT: "found a ship that a crew had sailed from Alexandria and was about to sail to Italy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: found a ship from Alexandria that was going to sail to Italy

contextId.information: You can make explicit that the reason they were sailing slowly and with difficulty was because the wind was blowing against them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: When we had sailed slowly ... finally arrived with difficulty

contextId.information: You can make explicit that even though the winds were not as strong as before, they were still strong enough to make sailing difficult. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: We sailed along the coast with difficulty

contextId.information: Here "they" refers to the sailors. It is implied that Luke, Paul, and those with them had not eaten either. AT: "When we had gone a long time without food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: When they had gone long without food

contextId.information: Paul is speaking to the sailors. It is implied that Paul also means that he and those with him will not die either. AT: "none of us will die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: there shall be no loss of life among you

contextId.information: The word "justice" refers to the name of a god that they worshiped. AT: "the god called Justice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
